mill_scene: ^The room smells of burnt paper and rain-damp books.
^A small fire flickers in the grate, struggling against the grayness pressing through the window.
^John Stuart Mill sits in a heavy chair, sleeves rolled, eyes ringed with sleepless discipline.
^He looks at you not as a sinner, but as a case study — a ruin to be measured.
^Mill: I have written that the good of the many outweighs the pain of the few.
^But when the “few” is oneself, that equation turns cruel, doesn’t it?
^Tell me — did your pleasures ease the world, or merely drown your guilt for a while?

c-0: ^ They were an escape. Nothing noble in them.
^Mill: Escape is never neutral. It leaves pain where you were supposed to stand.
^You ran from your share of the world’s weight — and someone else had to carry it.
c-1: ^ For a time, they made things bearable. That counts for something.
^Mill: “For a time.” A dangerous phrase. Every drunk and despot hides behind it.
^Temporary happiness is how suffering learns to disguise itself.
c-2: ^Mill: Then you’ve walked further than I dared.
^I once believed reason could justify joy. You’ve proven that belief naïve.
c-3: ^ There’s no measure that cancels that.
^Mill: Hurt is rarely erased, but sometimes it can be balanced — not in books, but in choices that cost.
^Balance begins with the willingness to lose. Are you still willing?

c-0: ^ Then yes, I’ll pay. If it means peace.
^Mill: A dangerous kind of honesty. Justice without ego can border on martyrdom. But perhaps that’s the cleanest arithmetic left.
c-1: ^ I’ve paid. The rest belongs to them.
^Mill: Then you’ve chosen peace over equity. The living always do.

mill_reflection: ^Mill rises, walking to the fireplace. He stares into the coals as if reading a slow, red scripture.
^His voice is low — conversational, almost kind — but every word is an incision.
^Mill: People think morality is a sermon. It isn’t. It’s a trade.
^Every comfort you take costs someone something — their time, their breath, their chance at peace.
^You, of all people, should understand that.
^He turns, his eyes catching the firelight — not angry, not pitying, just… tired.
^Mill: I spent my life arguing that the good of the many justified my own pain.
^You, soldier, did the opposite — you sought to feel better and let the world bleed.
^And tell me — did it work? Do you feel alive yet?

c-0: ^Mill: Then you are the perfect utilitarian product: a man reduced to zero.
c-1: ^Mill: Then tend them. The faintest spark has utility. Even faint light can hold back the dark.
c-2: ^ I lived. It wasn’t worth it.
^Mill: That’s the cost of unmeasured freedom — liberty without restraint curdles into appetite.
^You traded conscience for motion, and now call the ache “living.”

mill_weight: ^Mill’s tone darkens — the patience of a man who has seen too many moral optimists rot into cynics.
^Mill: I once believed pain could educate — that suffering refined the soul like iron under flame.
^But I was wrong. Pain only instructs those who already listen.
^He steps closer, his shadow taller than his body.
^Mill: You want forgiveness? It’s simple arithmetic.
^Do something — anything — that makes the world slightly less unbearable.
^And if you can’t, then at least die without adding to the total.

c-0: ^ One act, however small. I can do that.
^Mill: Then that’s morality enough for the dying — not a system, but a gesture.
c-1: ^ It’s too late to subtract anything.
^Mill: Every arithmetic of guilt ends the same way — the debt exceeds the lifetime.
^But the mind insists on counting anyway. That’s punishment enough.
c-2: ^ The world never cared about me.
^Mill: Then you’ve become the very thing philosophy fears — not a villain, but an empty man.
^The kind who leaves no pain behind because he leaves nothing at all.

mill_scene_end: ^The fire dies into a slow pulse of ash.
^Mill doesn’t look at you again — his voice comes thin, nearly broken.
^Mill: Freedom means the right to suffer for one’s own mistakes.
^You’ve earned that right more than most.
^But liberty without virtue is just noise in an empty house.
^He sets down his teacup, finally cold.
^At least it will mean someone’s still alive to make it.
